Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Sustainability in Supply Chain: An Innovative and Systemic Approach

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Sustainability is one of the top priorities for the United States and the United Nations. Environmental, economic and social indicators alarm us that our current model of progress is unsustainable. Increasing social concerns over the environmental externalities of business or daily activities urge us to seek better strategies to mitigate the negative environmental impact. Sustainable issues in today's long and complex value/supply chain should be immediately addressed. The current practice on sustainable supply chain lacks a holistic evaluation of the price of sustainability from a systemic point of view. Instead of measuring sustainability in terms of the entire product life-cycle, companies generally stay within their traditional approaches, which focus mainly on internal processes such as manufacturing and logistics. This EArly-Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) award provides funding for the development of a new framework for analyzing the price sustainability from a systemic view point. The outcome of this research, if successful, can fundamentally impact government's and companies' perception on sustainability issues in supply chain and also contribute to the field of Operations Research.

This project's product life-cycle approach to sustainability considers a wider range of activities and makes cross-functional cooperation compulsory. Each stage of a product life-cycle will be analyzed: raw material supply, product design, manufacturing, transportation, retailer distribution, consumer usage and disposal. Once the trade-off of each stage is fully understood, we can design an index for the price of sustainability. Upon computing these indices over the entire value/supply chain, given the limited amount of budget and resources, managers can identify bottlenecks and optimize on the total reduction of negative impacts on the environment. Mathematical programming techniques (e.g., solving a stochastic knapsack problem, or a dynamic resource allocation problem) can be readily applied to solve these potentially multi-objective or multi-stage optimization problems. In this research, innovative methodologies to analyze such complex systems and devise feasible solutions in a most cost-effective way will be developed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

Sustainability has become increasingly more important in modern supply chain management, and there is an acute need for more systematic approaches that help firms and organizations lower costs, reduce spoilage and outdating, distribute resources for more productive uses, and increase the supply chain's responsiveness to customer needs.

As part of intellectual merit, this research project delivered several new algorithmic frameworks and tools for solving multistage stochastic supply chain problems with a special focus on sustainability. Several important and pertinent stochastic supply chain systems have been thoroughly investigated, including remanufacturing systems with returned or recyclable products (e.g., digital product components, vehicle parts), perishable inventory systems (e.g., food produce, pharmaceuticals), and service systems with reusable resources (e.g., car rentals, electric vehicles). The PI and his research team characterized the structure of optimal operating policies for such computational challenging stochastic systems. More importantly, they leveraged these structural results to design efficient and effective algorithms, and showed the proposed algorithms admit constant-factor worst-case performance guarantees. They also demonstrated via extensive simulations that the proposed policies perform within a few percentages of optimal, and the waste reduction has been significant compared to existing methods and practices.

As part of broader impact, this research leads to significant advances in the development of provably good algorithms for multistage stochastic supply chain optimization problems with emphasis on sustainability. The algorithms and methods developed can lead to effective decision support tools for inventory and supply chain practitioners to carry out their day-to-day planning and operations. Moreover, they may also be of interest to other domains, such as theoretical computer science and applied probability. The project has also successfully yielded a Ph.D. thesis titled “Data-Driven Algorithms for Stochastic Supply Chain Systems: Approximation and Online Learning”. The Ph.D. student supported by this research project will seek an academic position at a peer institution, and continue this research path. Two smaller tasks of this research project have been conducted by two undergraduate students, and both have been awarded the INFORMS undergraduate research prizes in 2014 and 2015, respectively. The results of this project research have been broadly disseminated through publications in leading journals such as Operations Research and Mathematical Programming, and presentations at national conferences and seminars at peer institutions.
